commentBody: I ran the alphabet on the TENREC/CROCKER crossing and got the C, but I‚Äôve never seen a CROCKER‚Äôs. Which states are they in? Google isn‚Äôt saying, at least not based on my IP address.

While I wouldn't say I GALUMPHED through this one, 
it was not EASYPEASY.

Nice one, Barbara.

Hello all--
The Durham Wordplay group has been pretty dormant recently, but we're looking at a possible lunch or brunch, most likely in July. If you're in the area and interested in meeting up with other crossword solvers, send an email to crosswordgrrl at gmail.com (notice the spelling) to be added to the distribution list.
Fun mix. Slightly quicker than yesterday.
Seeing 35D (DIETS) as an entry brings to mind the quip: "I've been meaning to go on a diet, but I have too much on my plate right now."

The very first clue I filled in was Katla for Icelandic hot spot.  My good friends named their daughter Katla after a volcano there.

Was surprised a bit the answer was sauna, I associate that more with Finland.

That was brutal. 36 minute slog, but I got my gold star. Had to brute force for the REC/HYACINTHS crossing. Still don't understand why that's right. Obviously HYACINTHS is what it is, but REV or REF made more sense to me for the crossing.

NE corner slowed me down a lot, and I needed all six crossings for TENREC. Had smuCKERS in there for a while, but SPEEDu not being a thing made my realize my mistake.

Also, about 23D, obviously it's a valid clue and answer, but I found it very jarring. SAUNAs aren't exactly associated with Iceland. Using Finnish for the clue would have been much better clueing. If a misdirect was intended, it's a very bizarre one. Misdirects are good when they are clever or words with multiple meanings/senses. The hot spot part was good, the Iceland part was not

So the seed entry is 16 letters across.  That explains why my time was as slow as it was.

That, and the fact that I was watching the tail end of an unusually long (and exasperating, as it was a loss) Mets game.

And the fact that this was a relatively hard puzzle, at least according to xwstats.com, which describes it as Very Hard, with the mean solving time at 20:37, with the median solver 26% slower than usual (and these numbers will rise as more stats come in, as the earliest solves are usually be very experienced solvers).  80% solved slower than usual, and 60% solved much slower (that is more than 20% slower) than their average.

Today, DIANE was not a steak.  MORAYs are eels, not social constructs.  and BETTE is sitting right beside ASSES.  TENREC for me was a train wreck.  PAH is not a word I use.  Which meant 1A was the last headscratcher.  I, not big on mythology, was starting to doubt that LEDA was correct, but it was.  And I had to realize the party was TURNT and not burnt before I could see TUNIS (but not from my house). And the Intel asset wasn't a spy.

Enough of my RANTS.  Happy weekend, everyone.
Lost it with PAH. Tripe. Could be BAH, NAH, GAH. Take your pick.
First it was awful, and then it wasn't.  FINALLY got a toehold after many frustratingly empty squares.  The back-stretch went surprisingly quickly.  Loved this challenging Saturday puzzle.

PAH isn‚Äôt in my dictionary ‚Äî but I‚Äôm here to complain specifically about ANNE (MEARA), who you‚Äôve either heard of or you haven‚Äôt (I haven‚Äôt) crossing TENREC, an obscure term you can‚Äôt deduce from the clue if you don‚Äôt happen to know it. 

Obscure fill is something you expect when puzzling; it can even be fun when you can lean on knowledge of word roots, etc., to suss out. 

A construction that uses proper names and obscure fill as answers to matter-of-fact clues that cross like this isn‚Äôt a puzzle, tho‚Äô. That‚Äôs a quiz, and a clear sign the author painted themselves into a corner that the editor couldn‚Äôt get them out of.

Tenrec?  TENREC??  T E N R E C ???  When I saw it, I forgave myself for having to consult Prof. Google for some Madagascar fauna to find it.  Everything else was done except two letters, which didn't seem to add up to a word.

But otherwise, I'd say this puppy was TURNT, because I GOTCHA, Barbara Lin, and I had a lot of fun with your puzzle.  Thank you!
I thought this was delightful. Clue after clue with wonderful misdirects but none I could really complain about. Certainly not EASYPEASY but an enjoyable challenge.
Chewy puzzle with some tough trivia. Got PAH and MEARA via READPALMS and then brute forced the ANNE/TENREC natick for the Gold Star
Maybe crosswords aren't for me, this one felt like obscurity laced with eye-rolls. I've never heard someone say they "Hung a TV Set" for instance.

Done in by CROCKER, TENREC and, would you believe it, NOOK. Immediately realised crocker was a US brand I wouldn‚Äôt know, but missed nook, even going through the alphabet, because I automatically looked for rhymes with noon. Tenrec is new to me, though now I see it written down it rings a very faint bell.

Yikes. Maybe I‚Äôm too young, or too non-American, but this was a chore for me. 

GOTCHADAY‚Ä¶ have adopted a number of pets, and never heard this phrase. Nor do I ever want to again lol. 

PAH, ERST, REC, MPS. Hated these. 

GALUMPHED? Awful. 

Also, TREETOAD???? Is this an American thing? Even Google corrects it to Tree Frog because u know, that‚Äôs their name‚Ä¶ 

Anyway. Just a slog. Not fun. Glad it‚Äôs over.

Ooohwee!! I know I'm not the first and won't be the last to say but that was so not EASYPEASY! I had to settle for a blue star today but I'm going to focus on how much of it I was able to complete on my own and still considerate a good thing, and I had fun doing it! 

It wasn't going fast but I was able to complete almost the whole puzzle without aides.

"When you divide an odd number by an even number, there's always something left over."
"Oh, yeah! Thanks for the friendly remainder."

(I've seen multiple puns like this. I can only recall a fraction of them.)

I escaped by the skin of my teeth.

I think that may have been the hardest I've worked for a gold star, but I was engrossed the whole time (a little over two hours, if you must know).  The answers seemed so tantalizingly out of my reach, and often I found the answer I was grasping for was wrong.

I did myself no favor by spelling AIRES AriES.  

And having sexorgies instead of GROUPDATE was also a bit of a barrier, if not an amusing one.

62A [Small Roll] literally took me an eternity.  I know that sounds like an exaggeration, but I timed it.  An Eternity.  Maybe more.

One thing, though, and I'm sure I'll be educated about this from one of the dear people on this forum, but I was dead set on 36D being Detroit.  The Lions.  Maybe because they won a championship or two before the Super Bowl Era?

I suspect I'm going over a lot of material that's already been commented on, or will be commented on.

But, this was fun.  In my heart of hearts I thought I was going to be calling on the cheats with not even half the puzzle finished.
Great puzzle! Took me quite a few laps through the grid to a US everything out, but I enjoyed seeing it come together bit by bit.
oh how I wish they could all be this good thanks Barbara!

Congratulations on having completed the NYT weekly cycle, Ms Lin! I found this a bit crunchy, due to the witty clueing and a couple of mostly incorrect answers, especially fENnEC (which I should have remembered is a type of fox) and amaranTH. I had no doubt, though, about the wonderful NINA SIMONE. I regret we only saw her live once, when she was in her 60s. I have always loved her studio version of ‚ÄúI Put a Spell on You,‚Äù which has a fantastic sax solo (by Jerome Richardson, I think). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ua2k52n_Bvw
Surely all is forgiven. https://www.lvzoo.org/animals/lesser-madagascar-hedgehog-tenrec/

Wow. A lot of pencil today. Entered and deleted GOTCHADAY numerous times. I only have heard of this celebration for adopted human kids.

Luckily I had everything else right so I was able to guess at the Natick Square (_ROCKER?) to get the star.

Circled around many times before the end. It would be fun if NYT had the ability to record the solve and play it back in fast mode. (There's actually a replacement for Vertex out there called Nodes which shows you a replay of your solve at the end: cool!)

Regarding YARD:

Sun Mar 9, 2025 (Michael Schlossberg) 93D [48-oz. beer glass]

Thu Aug 22, 2024 (Brad Wiegmann) 37D [About 2 1/2 pints of beer]

Third time‚Äôs a charm, right?

Also, I don't think I've seen this one commented on but I thought 42A [Ballpark nos.] was a brilliant misdirections.

I had RBIs, I had ERAs, I don't know what all I had.  

Laughed out loud as ESTS.  He really got me with a wicked curve ball.
This one baffled me, and I'm from Natick.
Pah humbug

I almost managed to complete the puzzle without any aid.

I did the bottom third quite quickly, but had almost nothing in the top two thirds. Slowly but surely I progressed, however, making some educated guesses.

The NE was my undoing. I have never heard of ANNE [LEARY] (I had only A___), TENREC (___R__) and CROCKER (____KER). TM_ was a mystery. I needed to look up those four things. I knew the angel thing would be about investment, so I put in MONEY early, but only came up with SEED (S___) with those looked up crosses. TV SET... Clever! The singular SPEEDO always bothers me, however. I have only ever heard it in the plural in the real world.

I just looked up the Polish name for TENREC. It's... Tenrek (or kretoje≈º bezogonowy - litera≈Çy, tailless mole-hedgehog), and I've never heard of it, either. It's sucha weird word I will probably, and sadly, forget it within day üò¢

Unknows I dealt with without lookups included GALUMPHED, GOTCHA DAY, PAH, the fact one takes Ozempic once A WEEK (I started with daily), and FALCONS.

I really liked the clueing in this puzzle. It was on my wavelength, generally, but still very challenging, as it should be on Saturday at the NYT. That being said... Could somebody please explain "Words from a prof, maybe" - REC? I keep staring at it but I just don't get it, and it's not in the column.

Lords are not MPS. MPS sit in the commons. Lords don‚Äôt and can‚Äôt. The Houses of Parliament are two. 

Not sure how BATS swat crickets. I just hope this isn‚Äôt some reference to the sport. That would be an insult. 

The top right was very much not fun for me. While TENREC could be regarded as esoteric general knowledge, crossing it with ANNE Meara and whatever CROCKER was supposed to signify was just making things harder.  

Got there in the end but it took a while. 

Thanks

Oh!

Another one that blew me away!

40A[Relative of a skeleton]

LUGE kind of took my breath away, a little.
I somehow got through this in a shade under 20 minutes. It was a fun grid for the most part, but I do agree PAH sounds like a made-up word with a retconned clue.

PAH stands for Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension, which is what this puzzle gave me. I found it far from EASY PEASY, although I did manage to GALUMPH my way through. Eventually.

I have never heard of GOTCHA DAY, which sounds a bit like the celebration of a prank. At my house, we observe National Roo Day, with all the pomp and doggy circumstance the little guy deserves.

Pah?

I'm well aware of Betty Crocker, as in cookbooks, but grocery stores?

Where are these stores located?

Thanks!
I'll be extremely generous and assume the word "wild party" in the clue refers to the actions of an out of control or "TURNT" individual.

While I did enjoy this puzzle for the most part, I do have a bone to pick with 37D (Some Lords, in brief)

Lords are members of the House of Lords, while MPs are members of the House of Commons.
I also was befuddled by PAH. Still trying to understand how ‚ÄúGoes left‚Äù = HAWS

There were tons of head scratchers and off kilter clues for me in this harder than the new normal Saturday.  I didn‚Äôt know that NINASIMONE had written a memoir titled I Put A Spell On You and tried Jay Hawkins first. It fit, but just didn‚Äôt look right without the Screamin‚Äô, and of course it made no sense with the crosses.  I Put A Spell On You, the song, might be the only time NINASIMONE‚Äôs version of the song was less dramatic and emotionally intense than the original.  There are fun covers by Annie Lennox and CCR too, among others.

Ten double-EE's!  Or, to echo Thursday's puzzle, a DECTUPLE DOUBLE.






Et tu, emu.

I thought there were some wicked clues in this one including those for READPALMS, HIBERNATE, and SNAKEEYES. As a former virtuoso AIRGUITARISTist, and thorough nonmusician, I got a kick out that clue as well.

Many erasures today, which is a sign of a truly great Saturday puzzle.  Thanks, Ms. Lin!

 I usually know all of the animal answers, but TENREC was new to me.  The TENREC, CROCKER, TMC crossing gave me fits.  With _RO_KER in place it shouldn't have taken me as long as it did to see CROCKER, but the preconceived notion that I was looking for a grocery store chain name kept getting in my way.  

Another FRIENDLY REMINDER to be flexible.

After filling in the bottom four crosses, I had smuCKER for a second for the grocery store surname, but gave up on that because I doubted the pool wear would end with U.

I was stuck on the top left for a good little bit, until I considered the possibility that EEP could fill in that B___S space, which got me to SPEEDO, then to TVSET and CROCKER, to VENEER, to TREETOADS and SEEDMONEY, which took care of TENREC for me and got me through just under the 20-minute wire.

I‚Äôm always a little starstruck when learning that a constructor has ‚Äúhit for the cycle‚Äù. I was relieved to read that most of my fellow commenters struggled with this qualifying entry by Barbara Lin. I‚Äôve been known to occasionally suffer from the dreaded ‚Äúpuzzle shaming‚Äù when I come to the comments following  a brutal solve only to find it was easy peasy breezy PR territory for everyone else.

I thought this puzzle was a lost cause until I revisited it at 2:30am after letting the dog out for his nightly. (You could set your clock by Oliver, a wire-hair fox terrier who has helped me complete many puzzles and shed many a worry in the wee hours.) 

Despite the few issues with fill and/or clues mentioned earlier in the comments, Oliver and I thought this was an excellent puzzle to    welcome Ms Lin into the pantheon.

Kudos for including GOTCHA DAY.
Let's celebrate all the pet adoptions.

What I want in my Saturday puzzle is a riddle fest ‚Äì misdirects, vagueness, unknowns, lesser-knowns, and wicked wordplay.  And from this soup let there be a few ‚Äì but only a few ‚Äì footholds, just enough to get the ball rolling.  Where a cross triggers a pop, which may trigger a couple more, and where suddenly a smallish area of the puzzle becomes a beget-fest.

But let there also be areas of stuckness, where you have to dig deep, places you return to again and again in hopes of a revelation ping.

These are things I want on Saturday, and here they were today, bringing brain sweat, and reward.  Adding newness to the fray were eight answers never seen in the Times puzzle before.

Barbara, you found that perfect Saturday line beyond a trot and short of a trudge, and I loved this ‚Äì thank you!

Whew. One of my favorite constructors but this was a really tough one for me. Relieved to see that for once I'm not the only one who struggled with it. Eight debut answers and three others that had never appeared in a Shortz era puzzle. Was a bit surprised by that as most of those were fairly familiar terms. And.. had to go look at her previous puzzles. Here's one of my favorites. A Wednesday from August 2, 2023. A couple of theme clues and answers: "Starting with an X in the corner, say?" TICTACTOETACTIC "Rocket launcher that makes a whimsical buzzing sound?" KAZOOBAZOOKA And the other two theme answers: GOFARINFARGO TORMENTEDMENTOR Pretty amazing. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/2/2023 ....

I didn‚Äôt know PAH, but it‚Äôs in all the online dictionaries as an accepted interjection.  CROCKER would have been better clued as ‚Äúgrocery surname‚Äù rather than [grocery store surname]. I am learning that maybe I need to have more than one cup of coffee before attempting a Saturday. Gosh, that one was tough. Solved it without errors or assistance, but took almost an hour. The first half of which involved staring at an unnervingly empty grid.

Never heard of GOTCHADAY. Don't believe that PAH is a real interjection. Have heard of a TENREC. Understand the connection between skeleton and LUGE. Have heard of TURNT and GALUMPHED. Am a prof, but don't understand REC (yet). Loved "Go over some lines, say" for READPALMS and "Intel asset, for short" for CPU. Glad there was no question mark in "Gift from an angel" for SEEDMONEY. Connected ALBA to Scotland, rightly or wrongly. Old enough to know ANNE MEARA. Spent a long time thinking of family names of grocery *chains*, not grocery store items. Didn't realize that REDEYE is also a verb.

What an amazing Saturday puzzle! So much about it to still reconcile, almost an hour after solving it.

(Any real geologists out there appreciate "Icelandic hot spot" as much as this amateur geologist? Iceland's volcanism is apparently driven not only by seafloor spreading but by the island's proximity to a "hot spot" generated by a mantle plume.)

Anyway, my hedgehog hangups aside, this was a fun puzzle. GALUMPHED was easily my favorite entry. I liked the shout out to Watchmen in 57A. I've been meaning to reread it, as it seems more relevant now than it was 30-odd years ago. That clock is uncomfortably close to midnight.

Re: 37D Are [Some Lords, in brief] MPS?

Objections have been raised in three threads today, and in comments for earlier puzzles. I don't know the editors' rationale, but this would be mine. Yes, in the U.K., members of the House of Lords are called Members of the House of Lords; only members of the House of Commons are called Members of Parliament. But not all Lords are members of the House of Lords. "Hereditary" peers who are not in Lords may serve in Commons, and several such Lords have done so.

This puzzle was far too easy for a seasoned solver like me. As a native of Madagascar, I got TENREC right away. I also happen to work at a grocery store. CROCKER was an easy hint to solve. Nice try Barbara. Better luck next time stumping the best crossword solver on the island.

Hamlet says "PAH" over Yorick's skull; admittedly not meaning [as if] but more like [Yuck]. Uh-oh: did I just suggest another misdirect to the constructors and editors?

A smooth and polished grid chock-full of interesting answers plus some really fiendish cluing.  This extremely entertaining puzzle makes a strong case for more themeless puzzles in the NYT.  When you don't have to accommodate a theme, you can -- especially if you're as talented a grid-maker as Barbara Lin -- avoid all the short junky crosswordese that clutters up so many puzzles and focus on the quality of your fill.

What wonderful clues for READ PALMS; DECATHLETE; HIBERNATE; STAINS; SNAKE EYES; TV SET and VET.

I found this on the hard side throughout -- and very hard in the SW where I didn't know FALCONS, LUGE as clued and CPU as clued.  Couldn't remember what instrument was played in the AIR -- and STAINS baffled me because I had written in ?EINS thinking that the instrument would end in ER.

A real joy to solve.  Very Saturday-worthy, but without any suffering involved.

Man, I LOVED this one. The gradual revelation of what first seems impossible is my favorite element of solving these, and this puzzle really delivers on this front.

I love clues like "Goes out in the winter?" And fortunately I'm old enough to remember Stiller and Meara (but only from radio commercials, though). But could someone please explain the answer to 41A to me?

Quick solve for me today. Wasn't sure whether the animal/grocery store cross was a C or a K, but the rest was smooth. Was surprised by the sports franchise that never won a championship. I grew up kind of in awe of them. 

Didn't know the BBC had a Gaelic language channel. That's a language I've always wanted to learn.

Huh. I got it all in fairly short order, except for that one dang C in the upper right. I'd never heard of a TENREC (seriously, who has?), and even after looking up the answer I assumed that CROCKER was some eastern grocery store chain of which I, as a westerner, had never heard. (Professor Google did find a little grocery store in Crocker, MO; that's about it.) I had to read the comments to see that it apparently refers to Betty: a surname IN a grocery store, not OF a grocery store.

Hold on a second, a ferret doesn't look anything like a hedgehog. Oh, it's a TENREC? I'll have to take your word for that. French is weird.

As for 33D, I'm an actual musician, but I've been known to rock out on the AIR GUITAR.

I‚Äôm astonished by those who found this easy. This took 20 minutes over my 35 minute Saturday average. Definitely a worthy challenge and no complaints except for PAH, which is absolutely absurd. I guess there are some constructors who have a cluing style that is hard for even some experienced solvers to jibe with ‚Äî while other solvers just zip through quickly.

Some nice misdirections in this one.

I needed one lookup, the 36D "sports franchise" (whatever that is), to break into the SW, but otherwise chipped away at it slowly, and worked around a fair number of unknowns, include ANNE MEARA, CROCKER and SIMBA (which is just Swahili for "lion").

Celebrating pet anniversaries is a glimpse into a parallel universe for me, and I was intrigued to see GALUMPHED clued as ["Moved clumsily"]---it's familiar to me only as a portmanteau of "gallop" and "triumph". Filled BETTE on the crosses, stared at it blankly, and then belatedly remembered Bette Midler. Knew "gee" and "haw" from dog sledding, but HAWS took a while to drop.

Have never in my life thought of the SPLEEN as a "filter", despite being familiar with its anatomy and function. Seems obvious in retrospect, though.

I see that there's been a defence of MPS for [Some Lords, in brief] and SAUNA for [Icelandic hot spot], but I'm of the school that they're each a real stretch. While there are lords who have sat as Members of Parliament (thereby renouncing a place as Members of the House of Lords), and while there are saunas in Iceland (and I note the geological misdirection), these are not notable connections. One might as well clue them as [Some doctors, in brief] and [Scottish hot spot].

Or are there countries in which Lords are likely to be MPs?
I got myself all in a Saturday puzzle tizzy for nothing. It was enjoyable though if EASYPEASY. A full six minutes better than average.

@Man and 2 dogs But in the UK parliament, MP is used specifically to refer to Members of the House of Commons. A Member of the House of Lords is a Lord.

@NYC Traveler Generally the way it works (I'll admit I'm not very familiar with the American Congress system so I can't judge how accurate the comparison is) is that for a law to be passed, it must be approved by the House of Commons, who are the elected representatives (called MPs). The House of Lords is made up of people (called Lords, unsurprisingly) who have been granted the rank of Lord and are not elected by the public. The House of Lords does not need to approve a bill for it to be passed into law (they used to be able to, but that was changed before World War 1). However, they can delay the passing of a bill into law, and can call for the House of Commons to reconsider its decisions

@Michael members of the House of Commons and the House of Lords are all Members of Parliament. 

We tend to use MP to refer to an elected representative in the House of Commons, but that is just convention, and fairly recent (in the history of the Parliament), technically they are all MPs

@snufkin Despite Google AI's contentions on the matter, MPs are members only of the House of Commons. The title is reserved for those elected to represent their constituents. The UK Parliament website carefully makes the distinction between MPs and Lords, and I'm inclined to accept that as the authoritative word on the matter: https://www.parliament.uk/about/mps-and-lords/ However, as the example of Lord Thurso shows, if you lose a seat in the House of Lords, you can then serve as an MP. *But that prevents you returning to the Lords.* As soon as you lose or relinquish your seat as an MP, it becomes possible to return to the Lords, as Thurso did, under admittedly unusual circumstances.
